Recorded 25 October 2022}} }} {{Rishi Sunak sidebar}} '''Rishi Sunak''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|ɪ|ʃ|i|_|ˈ|s|uː|n|æ|k|audio=Rishi Sunak Pronunciation.ogg}};{{cite web |date=6 June 2023 |title=rishi |url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/rishi |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210428052456/https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/rishi |archive-date=28 April 2021 |access-date=6 June 2023 |website=[[Collins English Dictionary]]}}{{cite web |title=Sunak |url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sunak |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221025203727/https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sunak |archive-date=25 October 2022 |access-date=25 October 2022 |website=[[Collins English Dictionary]]}} born 12 May 1980) is a British politician who has served as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] and [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader of the Conservative Party]] since 2022. The first [[British Asian]] prime minister, he previously held two [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|cabinet]] positions under [[Boris Johnson]], latterly as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] from 2020 to 2022. Sunak has been [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Richmond (Yorks)]] since 2015. Sunak was born in [[Southampton]] to parents of Indian descent who immigrated to Britain from East Africa in the 1960s. He was educated at [[Winchester College]], studied [[philosophy, politics and economics]] at [[Lincoln College, Oxford]], and earned an [[MBA]] from [[Stanford University]] in California as a [[Fulbright Scholar]]. During his time at Oxford University, Sunak undertook an internship at [[Conservative Central Office]], and joined the Conservative Party. After graduating, Sunak worked for [[Goldman Sachs]] and later as a partner at the [[hedge fund]] firms [[the Children's Investment Fund Management]] and [[Theleme Partners]]. Sunak was elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] for [[Richmond, North Yorkshire|Richmond]] in North Yorkshire at the [[2015 United Kingdom general election|2015 general election]]. As a [[backbencher]], Sunak supported the successful campaign for [[Brexit]] in the [[2016 European Union membership referendum]]. Following the [[2017 United Kingdom general election|2017 general election]], Sunak was appointed to a junior ministerial position in [[Theresa May]]'s [[Second May ministry|second government]] as [[Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Local Government]] in the [[2018 British cabinet reshuffle|2018 cabinet reshuffle]]. He [[Parliamentary votes on Brexit|voted three times]] in favour of May's [[Brexit withdrawal agreement]], which was rejected by Parliament three times, leading to May announcing her resignation. During the [[2019 Conservative Party leadership election]], Sunak supported Johnson's successful bid to succeed May as Conservative leader and prime minister, after which Johnson appointed Sunak as [[chief secretary to the Treasury]] in July 2019. Following the [[2019 United Kingdom general election|2019 general election]], Johnson promoted Sunak to Chancellor of the Exchequer in the [[2021 British cabinet reshuffle|2020 cabinet reshuffle]] after the resignation of [[Sajid Javid]]. During [[Chancellorship of Rishi Sunak|his time in the position]], Sunak was prominent in the [[British government response to the COVID-19 pandemic|government's financial response]] to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom|COVID-19 pandemic]] and its [[Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom|economic impact]], including the [[Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme|Coronavirus Job Retention]] and [[Eat Out to Help Out]] schemes. He was also involved in the government's response to the [[2021–present United Kingdom cost-of-living crisis|cost-of-living crisis]], [[2021 United Kingdom natural gas supplier crisis|UK energy supply crisis]], and [[2021–2022 global energy crisis|global energy crisis]]. Sunak resigned as chancellor in July 2022 amid [[July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis|a government crisis]] that culminated in Johnson's resignation. Sunak stood in the [[July–September 2022 Conservative Party leadership election|July–September Conservative Party leadership election]] to succeed Johnson. He received the most votes in each of the series of MP votes, but lost the members' vote to Foreign Secretary [[Liz Truss]]. After spending the duration of Truss's premiership on the backbenches, Sunak was elected unopposed in the [[October 2022 Conservative Party leadership election]] to succeed Truss, who resigned amid another [[October 2022 United Kingdom government crisis|government crisis]]; at 42, he became the youngest prime minister since [[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool]] in 1812. Sunak took office amid the cost-of-living crisis and energy supply crisis that began during his chancellorship, as well as amid [[2022–2023 United Kingdom industrial disputes and strikes|industrial disputes and strikes]].{{Not verified in body|date=January 2024}} He has authorised [[List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War|foreign aid and weapons shipments]] to Ukraine in response to the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian invasion of the country]].{{TOC limit}} == Early life and education (1980–2001) == Sunak was born on 12 May 1980 in [[Southampton General Hospital]] in [[Southampton]], Hampshire,{{cite news |title=Rishi Sunak's Southampton childhood described in Lord Ashcroft biography |url=https://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/18865935.amp/ |access-date=26 October 2022 |work=Daily Echo |archive-date=24 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221024165656/https://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/18865935.amp/ |url-status=live }} to [[Punjabi diaspora|East African-born]] Hindu parents of Indian Punjabi descent, Yashvir and Usha Sunak.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-63345272.amp|date=24 October 2022|title=Rishi Sunak: A quick guide to the UK's new prime minister|access-date=26 April 2023|work=[[BBC News]]|quote=His parents came to the UK from east Africa and are both of Indian origin.
